title: How can I make this win-linux multiboot DVD?

forumNotes.author: Manala
forumNotes.content:
OK, here is the deal. I'm trying to make a multibootable DVD with Win 8 Consumer Preview, Linux Mint, Pinguy Linux and a bunch of iso-based utilities. That's ok, but I want a couple of folders with some files to throw in there too like "Drivers" and "Extras" which don't include anything that needs to be bootable.  

Now I've been working on this disc...project for 3 days now and I'm getting very very desperate. I don't care what tools I have to use, I just want this DVD to work. USB stick is not an option, because booting from it is not supported by this laptop I'm planning to install these operating systems (just for researching and learning purposes).  

To this date and time I've tried to make this multiboot DVD with SARDU, XBOOT and YUMI+ImgBurn. None of them have worked, all for different reasons. SARDU didn't support Pinguy, and couldn't get that working.  

With YUMI I made a perfect booting USB-stick, but I don't have a clue how to make a bootable\&burnable ISO/DVD out of it. Tried ImgBurn with different kind of options and boot images, but to no avail. If I try to extract the boot image from this stick with ImgBurn, it's going to be 16gb big, as is the whole USB-stick (only 8gb of data in there though, should fit in a DVD+R DL). So no burni-burni with that kind of massive boot images.  

Closest I came with XBOOT. I can make an image that multiboots all of my included OS'es and utilities just fine. But how on earth can I add just a simple "drivers" folder to that image created with XBOOT? Just plain stupid that this program doesn't have an option for that! I've tried to make an ISO with XBOOT, then edit it with PowerISO (just adding those two dummy folders), but PowerISO fucks it up. After saving that ISO it's not working anymore. Same thing with extracting the files (either with winrar or mounted to daemon tools) and then building it up again to ISO with ImgBurn. Just cannot get the bootloader/menu to work anymore.  

So please, someone, tell me how I can finally make this to work. I don't think I'm asking anything that is overkill, but still there doesn't seem to be a program(s) around which could make this to happen by just snapping your fingers...a couple of times. Any hints or tips how to make this happen would be much appreciated. So much that I could marry you and buy you a dog. If you're a girl. If you're not, then we're not going to have a dog. Thanks a lot anyway.

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
Does your PC have USB ports? If it does why not try Plop!  
You put put in a bootable Plop CD - the PC boots to Plop - Plop has it's own USb 2.0 driver - you can then boot from a USB stick from Plop even if the PC does not support USB booting.  
see [http://www.plop.at/e....bin.html#runcd](http://www.plop.at/en/bootmanager/plpbt.bin.html#runcd "External link")  
For reference see Tutorial #60 on my site (though that is about using Plop on a USB drive and not on a CD).  

Any DVD over 4.5GB is going to give you problems even if you can get all the options working. So I strongly suggest the Plop approach - it will be much faster to develop a USB bootable drive (see RMPrepUSB.com site) and use Plop to kick off the boot.  

You can make a bootable DVD if you include the correct boot file - see [http://sites.google....makegrub4dosiso](https://sites.google.com/a/rmprepusb.com/www/tutorials/makegrub4dosiso "External link")

urm ![:dubbio:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/dubbio.gif) , actually what you are asking (i.e. making a massive multi-boot, multi-OS supersize DVD)**is** difficult even for experienced 'rebooters'.  
The system you are using is obviously not suited to USB booting. Does your project **have** to work on that particular system.  
Why not test on another system or just use the RMPrepUSB 'test using QEMU' button to emulate booting from the USB drive (although it does not always work with all images). Or install QEMU Manager or Oracle VM Virtual Box and boot from the ISO file directly as if it was a DVD drive.  
Why not start by simplifying the project - get just one (smallest?) to work as you want (either as an ISO or a USB drive) and then add to it. If you have any trouble with any of them detail exactly what you did and we will try to help. As we are not sitting on your shoulder and seeing what it is you are doing, it is difficult to offer constructive advice.  

I know it can be frustrating, but we will try to help.
